bestBHT.bht: Jesus, confident in His intimate unity with the Father, prays not to request but to give thanks for the answer to His previous prayer. He is always heard by the Father, for they are One. In this particular instance, Jesus declares His complete assurance that the Father hears Him. He emphasizes this point in the presence of the multitude, demonstrating His divine mission and inviting them to believe in Him. This scene is not just a picturesque moment, but a pivotal opportunity for Jesus to open His heart about His unique relationship with the Father.

Henry Alford: At the same time He guards this, ver. 42, from future misconstruction, as though He had no more power than men who pray, by I knew that Thou hearest me always.
Because Thou and I are One.
When He prayed, does not appear. Probably in Peræa, before the declaration in ver. 4.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: Yet I knew that thou hearest me always, but because of the people that stand by I said it, that they might believe that thou hast sent me.
Instead of praying now, He simply gives thanks for answer to prayer offered ere He left Perea.
He did nothing without His Father, but all by direct communication with Him.
Albert Barnes: I had no anxiety, no doubt as to myself, that I should always be heard.
Jesus never prayed in vain. He never attempted to work a miracle in vain.
In all his miracles the ground of his joy was, not that he was to be praised or honored, but that others were to be benefited and God glorified.
Marvin Vincent: In view of the distinction which John habitually makes between the Jews and the multitude, the use of the latter term here is noticeable, since Jews occurs at vv. 19, 31, 36.
It would seem to indicate that a miscellaneous crowd had gathered.
John Calvin: He means, therefore, that there is so great an agreement between him and the Father, that the Father refuses him nothing..."
He had no need to pray, because he only executed what he knew that the Father had enjoined...
A certain fixed limit was assigned to miracles by the purpose of God...
Archibald T. Robertson: This confident knowledge is no new experience with Jesus. It has 'always' been so.
It was a picturesque and perilous scene.
This claim Jesus had long ago made and had repeatedly urged. Here was a supreme opportunity and Jesus opens his heart about it.
John Gill: And I knew that thou hearest me always...is also to his people, whose advocate, intercessor, and mediator he is.
But because of the people which stand by, I said [it]; that he was heard...their wills must be the same.

That they may believe that thou hast sent me: for if he had not sent him, he would never have heard him in anything, and much less in everything; wherefore this was a full proof, and clear evidence of his divine mission.

bhtAttempts.bht: Jesus, confident in His intimate unity with the Father, prays not to request but to give thanks for the answer to His previous prayer. He is always heard by the Father, for they are One. In this particular instance, Jesus declares His complete assurance that the Father hears Him. He emphasizes this point in the presence of the multitude, demonstrating His divine mission and inviting them to believe in Him. This scene is not just a picturesque moment, but a pivotal opportunity for Jesus to open His heart about His unique relationship with the Father.

Confident in His unity with the Father, Jesus expresses gratitude for the answer to His previous prayer. He emphasizes His assurance that the Father always hears Him, as they are One. In the presence of the multitude, Jesus highlights His divine mission, inviting them to believe in Him. This significant moment allows Jesus to reveal His intimate relationship with the Father and reinforce the distinction between Himself and the people.

Confident in His unity with the Father, Jesus declares His assurance that the Father always hears Him. In the presence of the multitude, Jesus highlights His divine mission, inviting them to believe in Him. This significant moment allows Jesus to reveal His intimate relationship with the Father and reinforces the distinction between Himself and the people. Through his prayer of thanks, Jesus reminds others of the power of his communication with the Father and His unwavering trust in Him.

In this pivotal moment, Jesus, secure in His unity with the Father, expresses His unwavering confidence that He is always heard. He seizes the opportunity in the presence of the multitude to emphasize His divine mission and invite them to believe in Him. By offering thanks for the answer to His previous prayer, Jesus not only reaffirms His direct communication with the Father but also showcases the distinction between Himself and the people. Through this heartfelt declaration, Jesus opens His heart about His unique relationship with the Father.

Confident in His unity with the Father, Jesus declares His assurance that the Father always hears Him. In the presence of the multitude, Jesus highlights His divine mission, inviting them to believe in Him. This significant moment allows Jesus to reveal His intimate relationship with the Father and reinforces the distinction between Himself and the people. Through his prayer of thanks, Jesus reminds others of the power of his communication with the Father and His unwavering trust in Him.
